Now Trump ’ s White House Takes the Statue of Liberty
The safest sign of regime change is when they start attacking the statues .
Americans value it as much as any other – hence the carefully-staged overthrow of Saddam Hussein in the Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the Trump regime ’ s key ideologues , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe to the Statue of Liberty in a heated dispute with CNN ’ s Jim Acosta over the president ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A Horde of boat owners and liberty-imitators would have lynched him if he had .
But he attacked their importance , and especially the importance attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to his base in 1903 , 17 years after the monument was finished .
As Miller complained , " I don 't want to go into a complete thing about history here , but the Statue of Liberty is ... a symbol of American freedom that illuminates the world .
The poem you refer to , which was added later and is not part of the original Statue of Liberty . '
Miller is factually correct , but as he put it himself , it is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary response to the stirring words of Lazarus , the only one in which a state invites not only some old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your mothers , your poor , / your oppressed masses , yearning to breathe freely / the wretched waste of your coasts ' .
There was never a time when the ' miserable waste ' was better visible on our screens .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism – he made clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict , because of the importance of a statue , is part of a broader political and cultural debate : it is indeed a conflict over America ’ s significance .
Lazarus - and her friends who sought to place their words at the base after their death - knew very well that they were doing a high-political act .
The sculpture was intended to show the links between French and American republicanism by portraying the female embodiment of freedom in a worn classical visual representation .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she has received a voice .
And she gives herself a very different name : mother of the exiles .
The combination of the poem with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
Just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , people on the right wing wanted to change this for a long time .

The great shrine , Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty was not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative that brought the American flame to the surrounding world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It is to carry the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch should not light the way to the United States . '
Quite unusual Limbaugh found something here .
The significance of the statue is entirely a question of the position of perception .
The great fanciful act of Lazarus was to see it as seen by the exhausted , miserable but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
It is truly a question of seeing the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Her statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome that they must hear .
And , of course , that is not the perspective that Miller and Trump ever want to recognize .
Their torch is not intended to illuminate the way , but to inflame hatred , which is their only source of power .

Poverty and Death in Indonesia ’ s Gold
When Bardina Degei cooks dinner , she does not use a stove .
It rarely uses a pot .

In her wooden house in Enarotali , the capital of the Paniai rule in the troubled Indonesian province of Papua , the housewife usually puts a sweet potato - locally called " nota " - directly into the fireplace .
After half an hour , the charred tulle is removed and swallowed with zealous , unwashed hands .
Degei sits on the clay floor - she has no furniture - where she also carries out her daily work , such as washing clothes with murky water from the nearby swamp .
A bucket in a roofless room serves as a latrine .
As the youngest of her husband ’ s four wives , she was not given any fields .
Polygamy is common here .
Of course , late work can be dangerous : most villagers are unemployed , and many drink hard , and there are soldiers here .
Nobody dares to walk around in the village after 5 p.m. ,  she says .

It is a rare insight into daily life in the highlands of Papua , a former Dutch colony that was admitted in 1969 after a controversial referendum in Indonesia , when only 1,026 elders were supposed to vote in front of the occupying forces by means of a public handlift .

An existing movement that campaigned for independence against Dutch rule quickly turned against the Jakarta government , which controls the region and excludes foreign journalists or legal observers .
In 2003 , the province was officially divided into Papua and West Papua , with the independent Papua New Guinea covering the eastern part of the island .
The journey includes a 90-minute flight from the provincial capital Jayapura to Nabire , a five morning .
There is no public transport .
The city of about 19,000 inhabitants consists of wooden houses surrounded by bamboo fences and corrugated sheet roofs , which have been converted into different yellow-brown tones by rust .
Very few Indonesians have made their journey here , let alone journalists and practically no foreigners .
Before Christian missionaries arrived , Mee Pago Papuans revered a god called Uga Tamee .
There have also been other changes .
We were not used to wearing these clothes ,  says Degei , pointing to her lively , hand-woven turban , her dark shirt and her bright skirt .
'Previously , we had only leaves on our bodies . '
Papua is Indonesia ’ s poorest province , where 28 % of people live below the poverty line and have some of Asia ’ s worst child mortality and literacy rates .
But it is Indonesia ’ s gold country as well .

The largest and most profitable gold mine in the world , Grasberg , owned by Freeport McMoran from Phoenix , is just 60 miles from Paniai , a highland province in the size of New Jersey with 153,000 inhabitants .
In 2015 alone , Freeport has mined $ 3.1 billion in gold and copper .
Papua also has an estimated $ 78 billion of wood resources .
But these riches are a source of misery for the Papua , ensuring that Indonesia ’ s powerful military retains a stifling presence .

Mass killings in Papua ’ s tribal highlands in the 1970s became genocide under the Asian Commission on Human Rights .

'We Will Lose All ' is stated in a 2016 report by the Archdiocese of Brisbane , which contains reports of last year 's atrocities , such as unlawful executions and torture - rape and electric strikes are particularly popular after another report - and the brutal repression of peaceful demonstrations .
It is difficult to count the number of victims because incidents happen every week ,  says Andreas Harsono , Indonesian researcher for Human Rights Watch .
The screws have strengthened as Papua 's resources bring an influx of settlers from other parts of Indonesia .

Indonesian President Joko Widodo , popularly known as Jokowi , promised to address the inequalities and violations of rights in Papua during his 2014 election campaign .
The former carpenter secured 27 of Papua 's 29 districts - including Paniai - on the way to the presidential palace in Jakarta .
But little has changed in Papua , and today the locals feel cheated .
Our hearts have broken because we voted for Jokowi in 2014 , with the expectation that he will fulfill our hopes that justice will be restored ,  says You .
Indeed , only two months after Jokowi ’ s inauguration in October , Paniai suffered a low point .
On December 7 , 2014 , a group of 11 children were out and sang Christmas carols in front of a campfire in Enarotali , when two Indonesian soldiers broke through the darkness on a motorcycle .
The frightened children told them that they should turn on their headlights .
One of the soldiers took offence at their tone and later came back with four soldiers , according to the local pastor Yavedt Tebai .
The soldiers who had drunk hunted and beat the group with their rifles , said victims and witnesses .
Then one of the soldiers fired into the group of children .
A child , 16-year-old Yulianus Yeimo , was so badly beaten that he fell into the coma .
A few hours later , the building of the nearby government commission was set on fire and things escalated the next day .
Around 1,000 young Papua men , women , and children gathered in a football pitch in front of the local police station and military command center to demand justice .
They wore ceremonial hunting bows and performed the Waita-dancing from Papua 's Mee Pago tribe , which was and imitating a bird song .
Some demonstrators began to throw stones on police and military posts .
